1.20.text: "Top of Mind" with Thom Ruhe, Video 25, 6/26/2013

2.20.text:
>> This week on "Top of Mind" we're visiting
with KCSourcelink, a resource for entrepreneurs

5.60.text: in the area looking to start companies.

7.80.text:
A model that has been replicated in over 20
cities cross America.

31.55.text:
I'm here today with founder of Sourcelink,
Maria Meyers.

34.61.text:
Maria, thank you so much for joining us today
on "Top of Mind."

39.61.text:
>> It's certainly our pleasure to have you
here.

41.82.text:
Because, of course, you're a special part
of the ecosystem here in Kansas City.

47.85.text:
And I thought maybe we would kick things off
by simply you sharing with "Top of Mind" viewers,

53.14.text:
you know, the history, what is Sourcelink,
the history and how it is we're sitting here

60.96.text:
Sourcelink connects together networks of resources
in regions across the country.

66.25.text: So you want to start and grow a business?

68.06.text:
We can get you to the right place at the right
time.

71.07.text:
Sourcelink started, wow, back in 2003, ten
years ago, here in Kansas City through this

80.26.text: And we started it to solve a problem.

83.10.text:
Lots of resources for entrepreneurs, the entrepreneur
couldn't find them no matter how hard they

88.93.text: Or if they found one it was the wrong one.

90.90.text:
So we needed to find the mechanism that would
allow entrepreneurs to find the resources

95.85.text:
that they needed at the time they needed them
to get something done.

99.39.text:
>> Well what kind of resources are we talking
about?

102.06.text: I mean, that's a pretty big and broad word.

105.20.text:
>> That can mean a lot of things especially
at the community level.

107.50.text: What type resources are we talking about?

109.32.text:
>> So resources that support entrepreneurs
are wide and varied.

112.78.text:
They can be financial resources, micro lending
programs, angel groups, venture capitalists

118.44.text:
who can help support the high growth entrepreneur,
or they might be incubators or accelerators,

126.38.text: places where you can go and grow your business.

128.29.text:
It can also be small business development
centers where people will sit with you and

132.32.text:
do one on one counselling for whatever need
that you have or help you grow your business

138.32.text:
We have people that are paid to do this work
from the government, the universities, and

145.48.text:
For instance, the Score organization is a
group of volunteers that support small businesses.

149.85.text:
>> We were able to catch up with one of Sourcelink's
first resource partners, Rick Miller, of the

154.60.text:
K State Extension to reminisce on some of
the early days of the organization.

159.63.text:
>> Community development means a lot of different
things, but we decided we wanted to offer

163.23.text:
some programming to startup business owners,
but didn't have a lot of resources at the

172.16.text:
That was about the time KCSourcelink was thinking
about coming together.

177.13.text:
We attended some of their initial meetings
and learned that this was really a way to

181.58.text:
bring all of the people in the metro area
together who provide services for small business

189.50.text: And we said we wanted to be a part of that.

191.36.text:
And really, selfishly from two folks, one,
from someone who didn't have a lot of small

196.46.text:
business background, by being part of Sourcelink,
we now were part of a network where we could

203.13.text: be referred from many other business partners.

207.19.text:
And all of sudden I didn't have to be the
expert anymore.

210.41.text:
I could now simply plug people into Sourcelink
so that if they needed business planning or

215.49.text:
finances or something else that I wasn't particularly
good with, Sourcelink was my answer.

224.09.text:
It was an easy way to refer people to the
best people who had information.

228.46.text:
>> So a lot of those support services and
those resources you just identified actually

236.67.text:
>> So how did you, for lack of a better way
to ask, how did you get them altogether and

242.65.text:
>> So when we started looking at building
the ecosystem here in Kansas City we decided

248.77.text: maybe we won't link together the entrepreneurs.

250.71.text:
Lots of other people were trying to network
together the entrepreneurs.

253.55.text:
And we said instead, why don't we link together
the organizations that are supporting the

259.58.text:
And so what we did, honestly, was we found
about 50 of them and got them in a room together

264.41.text:
and said, hey, we're here to help entrepreneurs
find you.

267.04.text: What can we do to help?

268.63.text: And they told us five things.

270.01.text:
They said one, make us visible, the entrepreneurs
don't know we exist.

274.69.text:
>> Most of our grantors don't give us money
for marketing so we're not very visible.

279.01.text:
Secondly, they said, hey, we don't know what
each other does.

282.67.text:
We don't know if we're all doing the same
thing.

284.74.text:
We would like to make good client referrals
to people that can help them but we don't

289.60.text: Can you help us figure that out.

291.77.text:
The third thing they said is, we want to deliver
the programs that the entrepreneurs need.

296.33.text:
Can you tell us where the gaps are in services
to entrepreneurs.

300.31.text: The fourth was we need more money.

302.74.text: Can you help us raise money for our own organizations.

305.21.text: >> That seems like a common goal.

307.21.text:
And the last one was can you help us measure
economic impact because the only way that

310.88.text:
we will raise additional funds is if we know
that we're making a difference in the community.

315.88.text:
So those are the five tenants that we started
our little network of entrepreneurial support

321.49.text:
>> So would it be safe to say you, in essence,
did a gap analysis for the community

326.42.text:
>> Uh huh.
>> and said at least on, I think it was the

328.74.text:
fourth point you made, and said like this
is where you all fit in the tapestry of what's

337.81.text:
Because in my travels and experiences I know
lots of communities that would kill for such

343.87.text:
Perhaps, and I'm setting you up blatantly
for the next question here.

348.46.text:
>> Is that perhaps how or the motivation as
to how Sourcelink or KCSourcelink went from

353.07.text: Kansas City to now a national profile?

356.62.text:
As we were building Sourcelink we created
tools that would allow us to do it easily

361.12.text:
and to make our entrepreneurial support organization
visible to the community.

365.15.text:
So that included things like a website, resource
navigator tool that allows you to answer some

369.87.text:
questions and find the resource that you need
and the tool that we used to track business

376.00.text:
growth and development, which was the economic
impact piece.

380.86.text:
And what we found was we had a turnkey system
that you could go into another community and

388.31.text:
say what are your resources and let's make
them visible and turn this on.

392.58.text:
So it wasn't long before other communities
came and said, will you help us do this in

397.28.text:
our own community, we don't know what our
assets are.

400.11.text:
They're not working together that we know
of.

402.42.text:
And we don't know if we're helping entrepreneurs
the best way that we can.

405.43.text: >> So how many cities are you in today?

408.24.text:
>> I think we're in about 22 additional regions
beyond Kansas City.

413.33.text:
>> And the regions are as small as White Water,
Wisconsin and as large as the state of Alaska,

419.45.text: Alaska Sourcelink; and big cities like Dallas.

427.36.text:
And small cities like a region right around
Rochester, Minnesota, Southern Minnesota Sourcelink.

434.44.text:
>> I think you're going to San Antonio soon
too, aren't you?

438.19.text: We should be in San Antonio by this fall.

441.39.text:
>> So as you go into these different markets,
you know, help me understand how you do the

446.69.text:
Does a team of your staff, you know, drop
in, parachute into the city and then there's

454.74.text:
>> You know, to get everybody to come and
meet and be seen?

457.28.text:
>> We believe that entrepreneurialship is
hyper local.

461.00.text:
What we do is we find a champion in that location
to help us build the entrepreneurial ecosystem

467.83.text:
So we find a champion and we teach them how
to do it.

472.13.text:
>> One of the things that we do first is go
in and find out, find who the resources are

476.81.text:
And we start by bringing those, that group
together to find out what their gaps are and

480.64.text:
what they need in their area and then we customize
Sourcelink to take them forward from that

485.59.text:
>> Maria, I was wondering if you could share
with me like an example of a program that

489.46.text:
Sourcelink offers that might be unique and
in the sense it can serve a multitude of companies

495.72.text:
of different types of industries, you know,
not like specific high tech or, you know,

501.24.text:
You know, like what's been a program that
you've had some success with?

505.94.text:
Let me tell you about our Battle of the Brands
project.

507.57.text:
You know, I told you we make our entrepreneurial
resources visible.

511.76.text:
Well, Battle of the Brands helps make some
of our entrepreneurs visible.

515.78.text:
We do every March we get together and we pit
64 different companies against each other

520.89.text: in our March Madness Type brackets.

523.24.text:
And we use social media and people have to
vote for them.

527.08.text:
And they make it through brackets and at the
end they win a pair of boxing gloves.

531.34.text: So it's Battle of the Brands.

532.91.text:
>> Now wait a minute, that seems like that
could be stacked.

536.22.text:
I mean, there's got to be some, you know,
companies in a given community that have much

540.74.text: more kind of brand awareness in the community?

544.08.text:
>> You'd certainly expect our technology companies
to win this one hands down, right?

550.27.text: It doesn't always come out that way.

551.90.text:
This past year it was a plumbing company that
won.

555.60.text:
And we had a lot of technology companies that
said how did that plumbing company win.

559.86.text:
Well, we found out from them that they learned
an awful lot about how to make social media

564.25.text:
work by doing this project or by having people
vote for them online.

568.68.text:
And they built beat the likes of our highest
level technology companies in this town to

576.33.text:
>> You know, I bet they probably didn't have
quite as an appreciation for technology or

581.91.text: Would that be a fair statement?

584.15.text:
And I think that interestingly enough in this
little activity that we did, I think they

589.48.text:
raised the visibility of their company so
high in the community that it really will

592.81.text: change the way they do business in the future.

594.97.text:
>> We got to take a look at those boxing gloves
firsthand when we talked to Jeff Morgan of

599.96.text:
>> Our marketing director, Tasha Everhart,
got us involved with KCSourcelink through

607.10.text: a Battle of the Brands contest that they have.

610.33.text:
We had been nominated as one of the companies
in town to be in this contest.

615.11.text:
And Tasha took it real seriously and said
we're going to get involved in this and we're

619.25.text:
going to push ourselves and see how far we
can go.

621.95.text:
>> Speaking of how far you could go and I'm
guessing this is why we have boxing gloves

625.43.text:
here in front of us, this looks like the kind
of thing you do for battle of something.

630.42.text: Was this part of what you took advantage of?

633.30.text:
>> KCSourcelink is so we've learned so much
in the last year from them.

637.49.text:
I just can't believe that we didn't know them
sooner.

639.52.text: And I wish we would have.

641.30.text: But they started this Battle of the Brands.

643.13.text: It's set up like the NCAA tournament.

647.85.text:
There's four different brackets and you battle
each team each week and get votes.

652.53.text:
The one with the most votes move to the next
round.

660.47.text:
And KCSourcelink was real smart, you didn't
have to register, you didn't have to give

664.78.text: All you had to do was go vote and get off.

668.02.text:
>> A lot of people don't like to give their
email address and do that stuff.

673.27.text: So they made it really easy.

674.27.text:
First there's 64 and 32, then there's 16 and
8 until there is one final team left.

680.21.text:
>> And you were the
>> You're looking at them baby.

683.54.text: So you won the whole tournament?

685.75.text:
I'm wondering if you were a bracket buster
for some of those earlier rounds?

689.96.text:
The second round we had to go up against Boulevard
Brewery, which everybody loves.

694.00.text: There's no way we're going to win, right?

697.10.text:
>> And we all laughed and were still asking
for people to vote for us anyway.

702.55.text: >> Then it was Gales Harley Davidson.

704.93.text:
>> Now Harley people and affiliates of Harley
Davidson, they know a thing or two about marketing.

709.62.text: >> They fought pretty hard against us.

711.15.text:
But boy we just asked and asked and asked
and asked and got online and asked.

716.92.text:
They told us it was okay to scream and yell
about who you are.

722.51.text:
>> I know we're coming up on a big milestone,
you know, the ten year Sourcelink anniversary.

727.44.text:
You know, can you share with me like what
that journey has been like?

731.01.text:
I mean, what's it felt like over the last
ten years?

734.42.text:
>> I know, it's a big question but
>> I don't know that I would have thought

737.86.text:
we would have been where we are today ten
years ago.

742.07.text:
>> When I started Sourcelink it was a white
piece of paper.

746.31.text: And they showed me my office.

747.93.text: It was a teacher's desk and 32 student desks.

751.55.text: I had no phone, no computer.

755.79.text:
And somebody told me what we need you to do
is hook entrepreneurs up to the resources

762.52.text: So ten years ago that's where we started.

765.81.text: And we had one year of funding.

769.33.text:
And desired to make something that was going
to last and be here longer than that one year

776.28.text:
So right from the beginning we knew that we
needed to create something that was scaleable.

780.96.text:
That we needed to think about building something
that would work for other people.

786.00.text:
And that's how we would make it sustainable
and impactful for the country, for our community

794.42.text:
And we actually wrote a business plan within
a year of starting Sourcelink, a real live

801.78.text:
And with our products laid out and our revenue
streams laid out and built a three year business

809.52.text: >> You still have a copy of that plan?

810.52.text: >> I do have a copy of that plan.

811.52.text:
And the funny thing is, I think it's the first
business plan I've ever written that actually

819.25.text:
We actually followed pretty much the steps
that were in the plans.

822.29.text:
The only difference was we expanded about
eight months earlier than we thought we would.

826.81.text: >> Oh, but that's a happy problem, right?

830.31.text:
>> I'm sure there were market conditions that
gave you confidence for that expansion.

833.54.text:
Speaking of that expansion, so here we are
at the, you know, the ten year mark, 22 cities.

837.79.text:
Now I'm going to ask you the bigger question,
right?

842.38.text: What's in store for the next ten years?

845.81.text:
One of the things that we built over the last
ten years is probably America's most accurate

853.25.text:
And we have found that it's very difficult
to keep those resources accurate.

860.90.text:
And we've determined a way to do that by working
with our affiliates across the country.

866.79.text:
So what we would like to have happen is to
partner with people who need those resources

871.59.text: and let us be their curators of those resources.

874.73.text:
And we should see Sourcelink resources all
over the place.

877.06.text:
You know, my dream would be the Federal Government
website is showing the resources that we pull

886.00.text:
And the all of our local websites that want
to point out entrepreneurial resources would

889.90.text: be pointing to our resource database.

892.01.text: >> Sort of like a Sourcelink.gov some day?

896.03.text:
So that's certainly an asset that we have
that we could really take advantage of.

902.47.text:
Another asset that we have is this very strong
network of people across the country that

907.53.text:
are working in a variety of different environments,
a variety of different economies with different

914.75.text:
And we have access to best practices in each
one of those groups.

919.23.text:
So to be able to share those practices amongst
lots of people would be a dream.

923.31.text: >> Like a playbook so to speak?

925.67.text:
>> Do you find, do you find much demand beyond
just kind of the network effect and what you

930.98.text:
do when you go into all of these other communities,
do you find additional demand, like okay,

935.37.text:
Maria, your team and you did so well here,
here's another conundrum we've been dealing

940.95.text:
And do you get asked to look at kind of like
additional services to provide?

949.90.text:
And I think we've done it many times now in
many different communities.

953.84.text:
And originally we were, you know, we did consulting
to help people figure out what to do in their

960.11.text:
community and then help them support it through
tools, tool development.

964.42.text:
But we've gotten to the point now where we
know a lot about resources and communities

968.94.text:
and entrepreneurship and could actually go
in, I think, and really help develop an entrepreneurial

974.62.text:
ecosystem within a particular region at a
much deeper level than we do now.

979.52.text:
>> I'm thinking on the ten years that you've
seen and all the help that you're providing

984.33.text:
for entrepreneurs all the over the country,
so I have to ask kind of as an I don't know,

989.09.text:
kind of like a closing thought
>> Uh huh.

990.53.text: >> Do you consider yourself an entrepreneur?

993.91.text:
I think that it's difficult to keep something
going for ten years without using some entrepreneurial

1003.62.text: We sit inside of a university.

1007.47.text: But we raise our own funds.

1010.84.text:
We determine our own future and we drive forward
that way.

1015.40.text:
There have been days when I wondered if we
would hit payroll the next time around just

1021.88.text: like all of those entrepreneurs out there.

1023.77.text: >> That is definitely an entrepreneurial experience.

1026.14.text:
>> We take advantage of resources that we
can find to help us figure out how to grow

1039.45.text:
We ask our customers what they need and want
to move forward.

1043.98.text: We validate our market all the time.

1047.43.text:
So I think we're pretty well established as
an entrepreneur.

1051.25.text: >> Sure sounds that way to me.

1052.47.text:
Maria, much, you know, success for the next
ten years.

1056.18.text:
Thank you so much for taking the time to be
on "Top of Mind" with us today.
